data.title: Was Gameboy a Miracle console at 1989 ?
data.meta_description: Even thought I caught the end of NES days and even played some Atari games when I was very young , but it wasn't until the very late 90's until i heard...
data.text:
Ryuichi Naruhodo

Oct 25, 2017

1,511

Oct 13, 2018

#1

Even thought I caught the end of NES days and even played some Atari games when I was very young , but it wasn't until the very late 90's until i heard about the Gameboy as I didn't see it at all in the stores and then several years later we got the PSP/NDS

So for whoever lived the early days of the Gameboy , Was the idea of a portable gaming device in 1989 with somehow NES graphics but in Black and White sounds like a miracle back then ?

Edit : Thanks for all the replies , I am not deep into the handheld history despite living in those days and playing NES so I didn't know the existence of Both Atari Lynx and Sega Gamegear so sorry for not looking deep enough xD and yea Both graphically beats Gameboy with no contest and as others said it was the battery life that the gameboy was superior in

Last edited: Oct 13, 2018

ILikeFeet

DF Deet Master

Oct 25, 2017

#2

no. the Gameboy, when looking at it from a specs perspective, was rather underwhelming. there have been systems with color screens and even backlit screens around that time. the switch's concept was even explored around this time with systems like the Turbografix Express

Oct 13, 2018

#3

It released when I was 9 and it was like MAGIC â€” puke green screen at all. I drew pictures of it leading up to launch and hounded my parents to get one at launch. Let's just say Mario Land and Tetris got a lot of play in the back seat of our Town and Country minivan with wood paneling. Those were the days. I also remember buying Solar Striker at Toys R Us based on the box art. That was a poor choice I lived with for many years.

#6

no. the Gameboy, when looking at it from a specs perspective, was rather underwhelming. there have been systems with color screens and even backlit screens around that time

Indeed. The Lynx came out only one year later, and the Game Gear followed a year after that.

The thing was Nintendo was the only one to consider the whole experience (i.e. battery life) which is why Game Boy flourished while the others were barely historical footnotes (although for Atari's side this was well into the age when they had trouble supporting any platforms at all, after the under-the-radar 7800 and before the disastrous Jaguar).

#7

Compared to the Lynx, its graphics didn't seem like a miracle. But the Lynx had other issues like a higher price tag and low battery life. The Game Boy was pretty awesome, though for its combination of price, portability, long lasting battery power, and quality game support. I got mine in 1990 and the first games I bought for it were Japanese versions of Burai Fighter Deluxe and TMNT.

The Lynx came out only one year later,

It was only around a month later in North America (a few months from the Japanese GB launch).

The library was amazing, however, so it blew everything else out of the water.

no. the Gameboy, when looking at it from a specs perspective, was rather underwhelming. there have been systems with color screens and even backlit screens around that time. the switch's concept was even explored around this time with systems like the Turbografix Express

So you're saying that in 1989 people weren't amazed and thrilled about this? They were just "oh it's not as powerful as this other machine so nah."

Because I may have been four years old in 89 but I distinctly remember begging for a Game Boy since the idea of having games in my hand was so cool. My older brother most likely appreciated his far more than I did too at the time.

#13

I think the "wow" factor mostly just comes down to a lack of precedence in the handheld market. And even though it makes sense to compare it to the NES since it was at the peak of its popularity in the console market at that time, you have to keep in mind that it was well over half a decade old by 1989 and computer technology was progressing at a rapid rate, so even though the Game Boy could equal or exceed the power of the NES components, it was still a very cost effective system for its time for the sake of price and battery life.

Oct 13, 2018

#19

Its a very good question. The short answer is no - from a marketing standpoint, the gameboy was outpaced by Sega's backlit, full-color GameGear. The Gameboy looked like trash in comparison.

But, when you looked at the long term value, things changed quickly. 4 AA batteries lasted forever in that thing (compared the the 6 it took to run the gamegear which lasted 2-3 hours), they had higher quality games with a wider selection at a much more affordable price.

It was not an experience of "I can't believe this thing exists! Was it made by aliens?" It was more "I can't leave the house without it because it works really well and Aunt Felecia's house is the most boring place on Earth."

Nintendo has always embraced cheaper tech to make their products more accessible to more people.

ghostcrew

The Shrouded Ghost

Oct 27, 2017

30,794

Oct 13, 2018

#20

To me, as a kid who'd never played a Mario game and had grown up with Commodore computers, it felt like magic. Playing Super Mario Land and Tetris was just incredible. But more because they were incredible games rather than a technology thing. But yeah, it felt like a huge leap from the game and watch style LCD handheld game things that I'd played before.

And, to make something clear, when it first launched it didn't have games with graphics like Pokemon (as that's the first example in your screenshots). It was Tetris, it was Super Mario Land (that looked pretty primitive with tiny sprites and barely any backgrounds). It was Motocross Madness and Tennis. Those later games were absolute marvels compared to the early games.

Oct 26, 2017

Oct 13, 2018

#21

Nah. The GB was not cutting edge tech. It was designed by Gunpei Yokoi, who was known for his penchant for using older tech and maximizing its utility.

The Famicom wasn't even that cutting edge and that came out in 83. Nintendo's key focus has always been profitable hardware. It was Sony and then MS that started going the loss leader approach to push better tech.

catpurrcat

Oct 27, 2017

7,842

Oct 13, 2018

#22

It was actually portable, which made a huge difference compared to other devices. Most people were used to carrying walkmans (cassette) anyways.

Then you add in tetris, and excellent marketing including very cool box art for all its games and you have a winner.

NoPiece

Oct 28, 2017

304

Oct 13, 2018

#23

Not a miracle. It seemed underpowered, and the black and white was pretty lame, even at the time. But like most Nintendo consoles, it was the great games that made it a great platform. At a glance, it looked closer to a Game & Watch in technology level than the stuff like the Lynx and Game Gear that came soon after. Also, Tetris was a huge phenomenon at the time, so it was a massive for GameBoy to have it. I remember going to FAO Schwartz in NYC and they had a bank of GameBoys with Tetris, and there was big line of adults waiting to play. Game Gear blew me away the first time I saw it, but it was unattainable due to price, and probably would have regretted buying it anyway because of the lack of interesting games (to me) on it.

No, it wasn't magic. It was crap hardware propped up with a huge game library. If only the TurboExpress had the same library, that was a truly magical piece of tech.

Battery life.

People forget that the lack of power helped with the battery life issue. My cousin had a GameGear and his parent absolutely hated the having to buy batteries for it all the time and they eventually gave up. Then add Nintendo's first party support and it was it was hard thing to compete with.

Remember this was before rechargeable solutions were mainstream.

#32

Hell naw, I've seen plenty of documentaries on the matter. It was cheap, long battery life, had Tetris, ect.

Those are some pretty important points! It might have been technically underwhelming compared to devices with a far higher price point, but when I was little, I couldn't even consider those because of the really low battery run time. Think Switch but without an integrated battery where you'd have to buy batteries all the time. I can't really remember, but I think, we only got rechargeable batteries for an affordable price later. At least in our home, couldn't find anything on the history of rechargeable batteries.

And it was introduced for the price point of around 70 Euro - you can't argue with that.

Every other handheld around that time was a luxury device compared to that.

Oct 13, 2018

#33

My first console.

The concept of changing cartridges in a handheld devices was great (but not new), but the graphics were really not impressive, at all. And it was sooooo annoying that the screen didn't have backlight, you had to play next to a lamp and put the system in the "perfect angle" to enjoy it. :/

But of course a lot of great games and great memories.

Oct 25, 2017

8,144

Oct 13, 2018

#34

I lived in those days.

I was pretty young, but I thought it was neat (there were already portable games, but most of them were all-in-one units, like Donkey Kong Game & Watch).

Yet, even my SUPER tech-illiterate dad said "next year there will be a Gameboy that's full color." There was already talk of the Atari Lynx which was backlit and full color.

I got the Gameboy and some months later the Atari Lynx.

So for whoever lived the early days of the Gameboy , Was the idea of a portable gaming device in 1989 with somehow NES graphics but in Black and White sounds like a miracle back then ?

How about a portable gaming device in 1989 that is backlit and looks almost on par with Sega Genesis?

THIS was some tech wizardry:

Deleted member 17210

User-requested account closure

Oct 27, 2017

11,569

Oct 13, 2018

#36

I disagree when people say the Game Boy had the highest quality portable games of its era. It's too broad of a statement and I think it varies by genre. I had all three of the major portables that gen and they all had software strengths. There are a lot of gems beneath the surface.

The Lynx's 3d games (STUN Runner, Blue Lightning, Hydra, Battle Wheels, Battlezone, Roadblasters, etc.) had no proper equivalents on the competition. I think the Game Gear had the best action-platformer with Shinobi II, the best SRPG in English with Shining Force, the best vertical shooter with Power Strike II, and the best fighting game with Fatal Fury Special. The Game Boy won the overhead action-adventure genre with Link's Awakening, I think it generally had the best beat 'em ups (Battletoads, Double Dragon), and puzzle games (especially for Tetris and Donkey Kong '94).

OP

OP

#38

Gamegear was the only console I had growing up (although I was no longer a little kid by its release date , more middle school) aside from Atari 2600 and my PC. Now that was basically a portable Master System, being back lit with color and had some amazing Sonic games on it.. The Gameboy seemed so primitive in comparison, but the real problem was that the Gamegear wasn't that portable because of its horrible battery life. I didn't have a TV in my room only a computer so it kind of worked out okay. Nintendo was smart in having such an underpowered and primitive system as it allowed for amazing battery life.

In the US when the Gameboy came out there was nothing like it. Your only option for portable gaming before it were those horrible single games with a fixed screen.

The tech was quickly surpassed, but for a year or so it was pretty revolutionary.

It didn't look like much next to the later portables like the Game Gear, Turbo Express, etc. though. Not sure why the more powerful portables didn't catch on. Sega even made a portable Genesis, basically the Nintendo Switch. But I only knew one person who had it.

#40

Handheld gaming devices weren't new right when the Gameboy came out, but what existed was stuff like this:

Or this

Both kinds had like three positions your character could be in, you couldn't swap games, and horrible graphics.

The other things being mentioned here like TurboExpress didn't come along until the Gameboy had been out for two years and they cost a lot more so nobody I knew had one until the mid-90s.

I first saw a Gameboy at the 1990 Nintendo World Championships, and at the time it was amazing.

Treasure Silvergun

Self-requested ban

Dec 4, 2017

2,206

Oct 13, 2018

#46

Hahaha, no.

But the Game Boy was the only true portable as you could play it for more than an afternoon or two with the same set of batteries. The Game Gear used two big batteries and burned through them like the hot knife in those YouTube videos.

The GB won because it was an affordable gaming machine, rather than an expensive handheld tech wonder that wouldn't last through a car trip across country.

But back then Atari made fun of the GB in their Lynx ads. They didn't get it. Just like the people today acting all disgusted that the Switch doesn't have a 1080p screen like their smartphone don't get it.
